awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of carbon fiber-reinforced, polymer recycling technology in the US marketplace. The lack of efficient recycling routes is a primary hurdle to the use of carbon fiber-reinforced polymers in automotive and other large-scale manufacturing applications. Such recycled fibers represent a new class of feedstock for composite manufacturers as their surface chemistry is unaffected by the recycling process and their native length and architecture is preserved, maximizing their physical properties and maintaining their performance. This technology may accelerate the acceptance of carbon fiber composites as a ‘green’ material by upcycling composite waste from the aerospace sector for use in automotive, sporting goods, and wind blade industries. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a novel technology to remanufacture carbon fiber-reinforced polymer composites from post-consumer waste into carbon fiber sheets and resin raw materials recovered through a recycling process. The proposed technology incorporates a  homogeneous chemical recycling reaction which utilizes oxygen as the terminal oxidant to oxidize key carbon-nitrogen bonds formed during the thermoset curing reaction of the polymer. As a result, woven carbon fiber sheets are recovered, still in their native architecture, with minimal damage to their surface chemistries. These recycled fiber weaves retain their physical properties and may enable myriad remanufacturing possibilities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
By this award, the National Science Foundation sponsored Travis Williams and co-workers at the University of Southern California to investigate the commercialization potential of technology to recycling of carbon fiber-reinforced polymer composite materials. The method involves applying chemical catalysis as a strategy for selective conversion of composite waste into valuable recyclates. The technology was originally developed with support from both NSF (CMMI-2134657, 2227649) and DoD (SERDP WP20-1491). 

In the course of the investigation of commercialization potential, the grantees discovered particular products (e.g. recovered chopped carbon fiber and bisphenol A) that could be adopted in the marketplace. They also found unanticipated market applications of the core technology in composite material bonding and repair. These findings were validated by interviews with over 250 industry players, including manufacturers, waste managers, chemical suppliers, and large-scale customer users of composite materials.

Intellectual merit of this activity is highlighted by the discovery that the same methods used to recycle end-of-life composite materials can also be used to repair in-service composites and extend their useful lives, thus minimizing the waste and carbon intensity impacts of the composites industry.

Broader impacts of this project include the creation of a company, Closed Composites Inc, that is delivering the findings of the sponsored research back to the American economy.


Last Modified: 10/07/2024
Modified by: Travis J Williams
